articles.headline: Bringing Along Baby Food? Not Too Much, Rules Say
articles.snippet: Faced with taking a baby on a flight, would you bring enough food to take into account the possibility of a long delay? One couple did, and ran afoul of the T.S.A.
articles.abstract: Faced with taking a baby on a flight, would you bring enough food to take into account the possibility of a long delay? One couple did, and ran afoul of the T.S.A.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAY you are traveling with your baby on a 2 ½-hour flight. The Transportation Security Administration’s rule says you may carry on baby food and liquids in “reasonable quantities for the duration of your itinerary.”

articles.headline: Democrats Make Populist Appeals Before Contests
articles.snippet: The senators are pushing their party further from the business-friendly posture championed by Bill Clinton.
articles.abstract: The senators are pushing their party further from the business-friendly posture championed by Bill Clinton.
articles.lead_paragraph: WAUSAU, Wis.  Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama intensified their populist appeals on Monday, responding to widespread economic anxiety and pushing the Democratic Party further from the business-friendly posture once championed by Bill Clinton.
articles.byline: By John M. Broder and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Germany Breaks With Its Clubby Business Past
articles.snippet: From the Siemens bribery investigation to the prosecution of illicit conduct at Volkswagen, the German business world is undergoing a painful national cleansing process.
articles.abstract: From the Siemens bribery investigation to the prosecution of illicit conduct at Volkswagen, the German business world is undergoing a painful national cleansing process.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT  It has become a familiar tableau in Germany during this season of scandal, even if the names of the disgraced and the details of their misdeeds change from one case to the next.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Carter Dougherty

articles.headline: As Lending Tightens, Education Could Suffer
articles.snippet: Commercial education companies are offering student loans as they scramble to ensure a steady stream of college-level students amid the credit squeeze.
articles.abstract: Commercial education companies are offering student loans as they scramble to ensure a steady stream of college-level students amid the credit squeeze.
articles.lead_paragraph: Major commercial education companies are scrambling to ensure a steady stream of college-level students despite the credit squeeze, with some preparing to offer student loans themselves.

articles.headline: A Savior for Chrysler? Read On
articles.snippet: Wall Street deal makers were shocked by statements in a letter to investors from Stephen Feinberg, the secretive founder of Cerberus Capital Management.
articles.abstract: Wall Street deal makers were shocked by statements in a letter to investors from Stephen Feinberg, the secretive founder of Cerberus Capital Management.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We despise all the public attention we are getting,” Stephen Feinberg, the secretive founder of Cerberus Capital Management, wrote to his investors last month. “We do our best to avoid the spotlight, but, unfortunately, when you do some large deals, such as Chrysler and GMAC, it is hard to avoid.”

articles.headline: Russia’s Claim Under Polar Ice Irks American
articles.snippet: A Russian dive that was the basis of a claim to nearly half of the Arctic seabed had American origins.
articles.abstract: A Russian dive that was the basis of a claim to nearly half of the Arctic seabed had American origins.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last August, a team of Russian scientists and legislators trekked to the North Pole and plunged through the ice pack into the abyss, descending more than two miles through inky darkness to the bottom of the ocean.

articles.headline: Pakistanis Deal Severe Defeat to Musharraf in Election
articles.snippet: Early results showed equal gains for Benazir Bhutto’s Pakistan Peoples Party, and the Pakistan Muslim League-N, the faction led by the former prime minister, Nawaz Sharif.
articles.abstract: Early results showed equal gains for Benazir Bhutto’s Pakistan Peoples Party, and the Pakistan Muslim League-N, the faction led by the former prime minister, Nawaz Sharif.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistanis dealt a crushing defeat to President Pervez Musharraf in parliamentary elections on Monday, in what government and opposition politicians said was a firm rejection of his policies since 2001 and those of his close ally, the United States.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: For Publisher in Los Angeles, Cuts and Worse
articles.snippet: Many at The Los Angeles Times are skeptical of David D. Hiller, saying he doesn’t understand journalism.
articles.abstract: Many at The Los Angeles Times are skeptical of David D. Hiller, saying he doesn’t understand journalism.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Hollywood Walk of Fame consists of more than 2,000 terrazzo-and-brass stars embedded in the sidewalk, bearing names from eminent to obscure (Strongheart the dog, anyone?). The walk attracts tourists, but most locals step over  make that drive past  without noticing.

articles.headline: Wall St. Banks Confront a String of Write-Downs
articles.snippet: Wall Street banks are bracing for another wave of multibillion-dollar losses as the crisis that began with subprime mortgages spreads through the credit markets.
articles.abstract: Wall Street banks are bracing for another wave of multibillion-dollar losses as the crisis that began with subprime mortgages spreads through the credit markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street banks are bracing for another wave of multibillion-dollar losses as the crisis that began with subprime mortgages spreads through the credit markets.

articles.headline: Health Plans Put Onus on Insured
articles.snippet: Let the patient beware. Going outside your insurer’s network of preferred doctors or hospitals could be more hazardous to your financial health than you suspected.
articles.abstract: Let the patient beware. Going outside your insurer’s network of preferred doctors or hospitals could be more hazardous to your financial health than you suspected.
articles.lead_paragraph: Let the patient beware. Going outside your insurer’s network of preferred doctors or hospitals could be even more hazardous to your financial health than you suspected.

articles.headline: New Trove Opened in Kennedy Killing
articles.snippet: The Kennedy assassination re-entered the spotlight Monday when the contents of a safe that had been secret for more than 40 years were unveiled.
articles.abstract: The Kennedy assassination re-entered the spotlight Monday when the contents of a safe that had been secret for more than 40 years were unveiled.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS  The Kennedy assassination  a defining moment in American history and a never-ending topic of debate among conspiracy theorists  re-entered the spotlight for a moment Monday, after the Dallas district attorney unveiled the contents of a safe that had been secret for more than 40 years.

articles.headline: Midlife Suicide Rises, Puzzling Researchers
articles.snippet: The suicide rate among 45-to-54-year-olds increased nearly 20 percent from 1999 to 2004.
articles.abstract: The suicide rate among 45-to-54-year-olds increased nearly 20 percent from 1999 to 2004.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shannon Neal can instantly tell you the best night of her life: Tuesday, Dec. 23, 2003, the Hinsdale Academy debutante ball. Her father, Steven Neal, a 54-year-old political columnist for The Chicago Sun-Times, was in his tux, white gloves and tie. “My dad walked me down and took a little bow,” she said, and then the two of them goofed it up on the dance floor as they laughed and laughed.
